message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on apoptosis pathways for help. Binding of a ligand to the CD95 receptor triggers the extrinsic pathway of apoptosis. A defect in this pathway can lead to autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome, which is characterized by excessive lymphocyte proliferation and autoimmune manifestations. Follicular lymphoma arises from abnormal B cells, while leukocyte adhesion deficiency affects the ability of immune cells to adhere to blood vessel walls. Chédiak-Higashi syndrome is a disorder of lysosomal function. None of these conditions are directly related to defects in the CD95 receptor apoptotic pathway.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The CD95 receptor is also known as Fas receptor and is involved in the extrinsic apoptotic pathway. A defect in this pathway can lead to autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome (ALPS), which is characterized by the accumulation of lymphocytes and the development of autoimmune disease. None of the other options are related to the CD95 receptor pathway.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The CD95 receptor and its ligand play a crucial role in inducing apoptosis. Defects in this pathway have been implicated in autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome. Follicular lymphoma is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and leukocyte adhesion deficiency and Chédiak-Higashi syndrome are genetic disorders affecting neutrophils and lysosome function, respectively, and are not directly related to the CD95 receptor pathway.

We refer to Google Scholar for help. CD95 is also known as Fas, and its ligand is FasL. In normal cases, FasL binds to Fas on the surface of cells to activate the extrinsic apoptotic pathway. A defect in this pathway can lead to autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome, in which lymphocytes are not effectively eliminated and can accumulate in the body causing lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and autoimmune disease. The other options listed are not related to the CD95 pathway.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The CD95 receptor is involved in the extrinsic pathway of apoptosis. Defects in this pathway can lead to autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome, which is characterized by lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and autoimmune cytopenias. Follicular lymphoma is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma and is not directly related to defects in the CD95 receptor pathway. Leukocyte adhesion deficiency and Chédiak-Higashi syndrome are both genetic disorders that affect immune function but are not related to CD95 receptor signaling.

We refer to a study published on NCBI for help. An abnormality in the CD95 receptor pathway can result in autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome, characterized by lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly due to an accumulation of lymphocytes. Follicular lymphoma, leukocyte adhesion deficiency, and Chédiak-Higashi syndrome are caused by different genetic mutations and are not related to the CD95 receptor pathway.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Binding of a ligand to a CD95 receptor triggers the extrinsic apoptotic pathway. A defect in this pathway may cause autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome, which is characterized by lymphoproliferation and autoimmune features. Follicular lymphoma is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and leukocyte adhesion deficiency and Chédiak-Higashi syndrome refer to defects in immune system cell function rather than apoptosis pathways.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The CD95 receptor is involved in the extrinsic apoptosis pathway, and defects in this pathway have been associated with autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome. The other conditions listed are not directly related to this pathway.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The CD95 pathway is also known as the Fas pathway, which induces programmed cell death (apoptosis) in cells. Defects in this pathway can lead to autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome, which is characterized by the abnormal accumulation of immune cells and the development of autoimmune diseases. Option A, follicular lymphoma, is a type of cancer that arises from B cells, but it is not directly related to defects in the CD95 pathway. Option B, leukocyte adhesion deficiency, is caused by mutations in genes that encode for integrins, which are involved in cell adhesion and migration, and is not directly related to defects in the CD95 pathway. Option C, Chédiak-Higashi syndrome, is a rare genetic disorder that affects lysosomal function and leads to immune system dysfunction, but it is not directly related to defects in the CD95 pathway.

We refer to medical research articles for help. The CD95 pathway, also known as the Fas pathway, is involved in apoptosis of activated T cells. A defect in this pathway can result in autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome, which is characterized by the accumulation of lymphocytes and autoimmune symptoms. The other options listed are not associated with defects in the CD95 pathway.
